elements.content: Described is the creation, deployment, and evaluation of a video produced about the synthesis and applications of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). The goal of this project was to gauge the impact of viewing the video on high school students’ conceptions of authentic chemistry practices and applications. Additionally, comparisons were made between the use of the video and more traditional face-to-face presentations given by professional scientists. Observations, student surveys, and an interview with the high school chemistry teacher demonstrated the utility of such a video. Specifically, the students who viewed the video reported learning more about the nature of laboratory work in chemistry than other students who did not view the video. Students, regardless of whether they viewed the video or just received a presentation, reported growth in understandings of the applications of chemistry research and porous nanomaterial. Other research chemists are encouraged to consider ways that they could document on video the research that they are performing in order to introduce an untapped audience (high school students) to authentic chemistry research in a practically simple manner. During times of crisis, such as a pandemic, online videos could be a useful tool for high school chemistry teachers to use in collaboration with research faculty, particularly when schools are closed.
elements.clean_text: Described is the creation, deployment, and evaluation of a video produced about the synthesis and applications of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). The goal of this project was to gauge the impact of viewing the video on high school students' conceptions of authentic chemistry practices and applications. Additionally, comparisons were made between the use of the video and more traditional face-to-face presentations given by professional scientists. Observations, student surveys, and an interview with the high school chemistry teacher demonstrated the utility of such a video. Specifically, the students who viewed the video reported learning more about the nature of laboratory work in chemistry than other students who did not view the video. Students, regardless of whether they viewed the video or just received a presentation, reported growth in understandings of the applications of chemistry research and porous nanomaterial. Other research chemists are encouraged to consider ways that they could document on video the research that they are performing in order to introduce an untapped audience (high school students) to authentic chemistry research in a practically simple manner. During times of crisis, such as a pandemic, online videos could be a useful tool for high school chemistry teachers to use in collaboration with research faculty, particularly when schools are closed.

elements.content: High school chemistry, along with other science subjects, is often taught in a manner that is quite removed from the actual research practices that occur in university and other professional laboratory settings. There are many justifiable reasons for this reality. For one, high schools lack the resources to fully stock a laboratory with the necessary chemicals and instrumental tools. Additionally, a high school chemistry classroom typically has a student to teacher ratio that would make truly authentic involvement in cutting edge chemical research virtually impossible. Complicating matters is the reality that many high school chemistry teachers lack important disciplinary specific background and experiences that would equip them to give a more realistic portrayal of professional chemistry to their students.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

High school chemistry, along with other science subjects, is often taught in a manner that is quite removed from the actual research practices that occur in university and other professional laboratory settings. There are many justifiable reasons for this reality. For one, high schools lack the resources to fully stock a laboratory with the necessary chemicals and instrumental tools. Additionally, a high school chemistry classroom typically has a student to teacher ratio that would make truly authentic involvement in cutting edge chemical research virtually impossible. Complicating matters is the reality that many high school chemistry teachers lack important disciplinary specific background and experiences that would equip them to give a more realistic portrayal of professional chemistry to their students.

elements.content: Research apprenticeship experiences designed for high school students in authentic laboratory contexts are one avenue by which these learners can be exposed to the real-world of chemistry research. Research about the impacts of these experiences have demonstrated that the participants learn science content, develop confidence in their abilities to participate meaningfully in scientific discovery, and learn more about the Nature of Science (NOS) as a direct result of their participation. One problem with these experiences is the large number of barriers to access them. They are often expensive and elite and have limited space. They are also informal in that they are not a part of any formal curriculum and typically take place over the summer. This timing could conflict with other plans held by students and host faculty.
elements.clean_text: Research apprenticeship experiences designed for high school students in authentic laboratory contexts are one avenue by which these learners can be exposed to the real-world of chemistry research. Research about the impacts of these experiences have demonstrated that the participants learn science content, develop confidence in their abilities to participate meaningfully in scientific discovery, and learn more about the Nature of Science (NOS) as a direct result of their participation. One problem with these experiences is the large number of barriers to access them. They are often expensive and elite and have limited space. They are also informal in that they are not a part of any formal curriculum and typically take place over the summer. This timing could conflict with other plans held by students and host faculty.

elements.content: In response to some of these issues, science educators have attempted to bring professional scientists and their laboratories into the high school classroom. These School Scientist Partnerships (SSPs) have resulted in mixed success. They could involve the scientist sharing her research in a lecture format or allowing the students to somehow participate in data collection or a similar experience. If the students do participate in data collection, rarely if ever do they actually get to participate in the data analysis or experience what happens next in the research process as it moves toward publication and presentation. What is clear from the above discussion is that high school chemistry learners have limited experience with or opportunities to examine just what it is that professional chemists do and how their research makes a genuine contribution to solving ongoing global problems. We, along with a number of science educators, believe that a lack of an adequate understanding of the authentic work done by scientists in professional contexts could be setting up incoming undergraduate students with a misunderstanding about the meaningfulness and significance of scientific research as well as the practices employed in the research laboratory.
elements.clean_text: In response to some of these issues, science educators have attempted to bring professional scientists and their laboratories into the high school classroom. These School Scientist Partnerships (SSPs) have resulted in mixed success. They could involve the scientist sharing her research in a lecture format or allowing the students to somehow participate in data collection or a similar experience. If the students do participate in data collection, rarely if ever do they actually get to participate in the data analysis or experience what happens next in the research process as it moves toward publication and presentation. What is clear from the above discussion is that high school chemistry learners have limited experience with or opportunities to examine just what it is that professional chemists do and how their research makes a genuine contribution to solving ongoing global problems. We, along with a number of science educators, believe that a lack of an adequate understanding of the authentic work done by scientists in professional contexts could be setting up incoming undergraduate students with a misunderstanding about the meaningfulness and significance of scientific research as well as the practices employed in the research laboratory.

elements.content: It is our belief that videos could be utilized to virtually bring the professional laboratory into a high school classroom in a way that otherwise would not be possible. Online videos have been specifically used to teach chemical concepts and content, prepare students for laboratory work with a certain degree of success, provide instruction and practice in chemical information literacy, and/or allow students to demonstrate their own chemical knowledge and understanding. In addition to these uses, YouTube has been utilized to showcase and communicate science more generally to an informal public audience through publically available videos. Less frequently have professional scientists developed their own videos to communicate the specifics of their research. It is here where this work makes a contribution to the chemistry education literature in that it offers an additional example of the creation of a video that could be replicated by other chemists to disseminate their research to the general public in a novel way. Specifically, we believe that a video tour of a working chemistry laboratory can allow for high school students to see into a laboratory in a way that a more traditional classroom visit from a professional chemist would not afford.
elements.clean_text: It is our belief that videos could be utilized to virtually bring the professional laboratory into a high school classroom in a way that otherwise would not be possible. Online videos have been specifically used to teach chemical concepts and content, prepare students for laboratory work with a certain degree of success, provide instruction and practice in chemical information literacy, and/or allow students to demonstrate their own chemical knowledge and understanding. In addition to these uses, YouTube has been utilized to showcase and communicate science more generally to an informal public audience through publically available videos. Less frequently have professional scientists developed their own videos to communicate the specifics of their research. It is here where this work makes a contribution to the chemistry education literature in that it offers an additional example of the creation of a video that could be replicated by other chemists to disseminate their research to the general public in a novel way. Specifically, we believe that a video tour of a working chemistry laboratory can allow for high school students to see into a laboratory in a way that a more traditional classroom visit from a professional chemist would not afford.

elements.content: The purpose of this work is to report on a collaboration between a chemist and science educator at a major research university that resulted in the development and implementation of a documentary film showcasing the chemist’s research, aimed at an audience of high school chemistry students. The result was a new understanding of the benefits of, and the potential for, using video technologies to introduce high school students to authentic scientific research that would be otherwise near to impossible to achieve for a large number of students.
elements.clean_text: The purpose of this work is to report on a collaboration between a chemist and science educator at a major research university that resulted in the development and implementation of a documentary film showcasing the chemist's research, aimed at an audience of high school chemistry students. The result was a new understanding of the benefits of, and the potential for, using video technologies to introduce high school students to authentic scientific research that would be otherwise near to impossible to achieve for a large number of students.

elements.content: The chemistry content that was the focus of the video dealt with metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as this is the main focus of one area of the author’s scholarly research. MOFs are microscopic particles with large surface areas that are porous and can be used therefore in the adsorption of certain target chemicals and/or to deliver target chemicals stored within them to specific active sites often for medical purposes. Additionally, these substances are crystalline in nature and as such hold very specific molecular geometries that can be viewed via transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM), the latter of which produces nice three-dimensional images. displays the synthesis process and chemical structures for the MOFs utilized in this project. displays images from the utilization of SEM and TEM at the research university (University of Arkansas) to view MOF-5.
elements.clean_text:
Design

The chemistry content that was the focus of the video dealt with metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as this is the main focus of one area of the author's scholarly research. MOFs are microscopic particles with large surface areas that are porous and can be used therefore in the adsorption of certain target chemicals and/or to deliver target chemicals stored within them to specific active sites often for medical purposes. Additionally, these substances are crystalline in nature and as such hold very specific molecular geometries that can be viewed via transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM), the latter of which produces nice three-dimensional images.  displays the synthesis process and chemical structures for the MOFs utilized in this project.  displays images from the utilization of SEM and TEM at the research university (University of Arkansas) to view MOF-5.

elements.content: Synthesis and structural representations of the three different MOFs (MIL-101­(Fe), ZIF-8, and MOF-5) used for this study.

elements.content: Transmission electron microscopy (A) and scanning electron microscopy (B–F) images of the metal organic framework (MOF-5) that was synthesized for this project.
elements.clean_text: 2  Transmission electron microscopy (A) and scanning electron microscopy (B-F) images of the metal organic framework (MOF-5) that was synthesized for this project.

elements.content: A documentary-style film was created with the intent purpose of having it viewed by high school chemistry students in a classroom setting at an area high school. The video that was generated contained a tour of the chemistry laboratory space, the steps used in the synthesis of the MOF, the operation of both the TEM and the SEM to view the MOFs, a demonstration of the adsorption capabilities of the synthesized MOF, and a discussion of MOF properties and applications. In editing the video, decisions were made to cut between lecture-style slide presentations and video footage of laboratory techniques and procedures so as to make the video more engaging and to flow in a logical way. The video footage was taken with a Sony Handycam Camcorder typically used for recording personal home videos and then edited with the iMovie video editing software. The point is that this video was made using very inexpensive equipment and software. displays a screenshot from the YouTube video that we created. The video itself was nearly 30 min in length. The link to this video can be found in the Associated Content section at the conclusion of this communication. Our rationale for uploading the video to YouTube was for the benefit of the chemistry teacher to easily access the video in his various classes. A secondary benefit, unexamined in this work as it was unrelated to the scope of this project, was the ability for the general public to find and view the video on YouTube at their leisure. Within a year of its posting, the video itself has over 6500 views on YouTube.

The video that was generated contained a tour of the chemistry laboratory space, the steps used in the synthesis of the MOF, the operation of both the TEM and the SEM to view the MOFs, a demonstration of the adsorption capabilities of the synthesized MOF, and a discussion of MOF properties and applications. In editing the video, decisions were made to cut between lecture-style slide presentations and video footage of laboratory techniques and procedures so as to make the video more engaging and to flow in a logical way. The video footage was taken with a Sony Handycam Camcorder typically used for recording personal home videos and then edited with the iMovie video editing software. The point is that this video was made using very inexpensive equipment and software.  displays a screenshot from the YouTube video that we created. The video itself was nearly 30 min in length. Our rationale for uploading the video to YouTube was for the benefit of the chemistry teacher to easily access the video in his various classes. A secondary benefit, unexamined in this work as it was unrelated to the scope of this project, was the ability for the general public to find and view the video on YouTube at their leisure. Within a year of its posting, the video itself has over 6500 views on YouTube.

elements.content: One chemistry teacher and 122 of his students (from multiple class periods) from a local high school (Fayetteville High School (FHS)) participated in this study. The high school itself has an enrollment of over 2800 students. Of the total students, 69% are White, 13% Hispanic, and 11% Black. 22% of the students are on free and reduced lunch. 49% of the students participate in Advanced Placement (AP) course work. The students in this study were representative of the overall student population.
elements.clean_text:
Methods

One chemistry teacher and 122 of his students (from multiple class periods) from a local high school (Fayetteville High School (FHS)) participated in this study. The high school itself has an enrollment of over 2800 students. Of the total students, 69% are White, 13% Hispanic, and 11% Black. 22% of the students are on free and reduced lunch. 49% of the students participate in Advanced Placement (AP) course work. The students in this study were representative of the overall student population.

elements.content: We examined five different chemistry classes for the purposes of this investigation. Three of them were standard introductory high school chemistry classes and two were pre-AP chemistry classes. The three standard classes received one of three treatments: A, a traditional research presentation by the chemist without the video; B, viewing the video in the presence of the chemist to field questions; C, viewing the video in the absence of the chemist. The two pre-AP classes received one of the two treatments outlined above: A, a traditional research presentation by the chemist without the video; C, viewing the video in the absence of the chemist.
elements.clean_text: We examined five different chemistry classes for the purposes of this investigation. Three of them were standard introductory high school chemistry classes and two were pre-AP chemistry classes. The three standard classes received one of three treatments: A, a traditional research presentation by the chemist without the video; B, viewing the video in the presence of the chemist to field questions; C, viewing the video in the absence of the chemist. The two pre-AP classes received one of the two treatments outlined above: A, a traditional research presentation by the chemist without the video; C, viewing the video in the absence of the chemist.

elements.content: Students from all five of the classes were surveyed about their beliefs regarding the impact of the video. Additionally, three class periods were observed as they viewed the video and/or participated in a live presentation made by the research chemist. Finally, the teacher was interviewed about his thoughts on the merits and intended purposes of the video. These mixed-methods observational and interview data were analyzed using qualitative methodologies consistent with those employed when conducting naturalistic forms of inquiry.
elements.clean_text: Students from all five of the classes were surveyed about their beliefs regarding the impact of the video. Additionally, three class periods were observed as they viewed the video and/or participated in a live presentation made by the research chemist. Finally, the teacher was interviewed about his thoughts on the merits and intended purposes of the video. These mixed-methods observational and interview data were analyzed using qualitative methodologies consistent with those employed when conducting naturalistic forms of inquiry.

elements.content:
Students from each group were surveyed about the impact of the experience. displays the percentages of students from each class that self-reported learning as a result of the video or presentation.

This survey () consisted of open-ended questions to which students provided written responses. When students wrote about the use of MOFs as either a drug delivery system or as a means of water purification on the survey, their response was classified as “applications of chemistry”. Students describing a new understanding of the work that a chemist does had their responses labeled as “job of a chemist”. When students discussed laboratory processes such as the microscopy viewed in the video, their responses were coded, “authentic laboratory work”. A number of students described learning about porous materials or about chemistry in general, and their responses were described as “miscellaneous learning”. Finally, some students were quite blunt when telling us that they did not think they learned anything at all. Such responses were indicative of “no learning”.
elements.clean_text:
Findings

Student Reported Impact

Students from each group were surveyed about the impact of the experience.  displays the percentages of students from each class that self-reported learning as a result of the video or presentation.

This survey () consisted of open-ended questions to which students provided written responses. When students wrote about the use of MOFs as either a drug delivery system or as a means of water purification on the survey, their response was classified as "applications of chemistry". Students describing a new understanding of the work that a chemist does had their responses labeled as "job of a chemist". When students discussed laboratory processes such as the microscopy viewed in the video, their responses were coded, "authentic laboratory work". A number of students described learning about porous materials or about chemistry in general, and their responses were described as "miscellaneous learning". Finally, some students were quite blunt when telling us that they did not think they learned anything at all. Such responses were indicative of "no learning".

In all three of the classes that we observed, students were attentive to either the video or the presentation and asked a variety of questions to the chemist when present. Most of these questions centered on the application of MOF chemistry, specifically the time it takes to take a drug from the research stage to its availability to the general public.
elements.clean_text:
Observations

In all three of the classes that we observed, students were attentive to either the video or the presentation and asked a variety of questions to the chemist when present. Most of these questions centered on the application of MOF chemistry, specifically the time it takes to take a drug from the research stage to its availability to the general public.

elements.content: The teacher was interviewed about his thoughts on what the students may have gained from their viewing of the video. During that interview, he expressed his belief that for “one hundred percent” of his students this was their first window into what a working laboratory was like. He said that what they do in his classroom is “prescribed a lot and not so much experimentation. [Through the video] they could see the difference between a [school] lab and a [professional] experiment”.
elements.clean_text:
Teacher Perspectives

The teacher was interviewed about his thoughts on what the students may have gained from their viewing of the video. During that interview, he expressed his belief that for "one hundred percent" of his students this was their first window into what a working laboratory was like. He said that what they do in his classroom is "prescribed a lot and not so much experimentation. [Through the video] they could see the difference between a [school] lab and a [professional] experiment".

elements.content: As can be seen from the data presented in , students in general reported learning something as a result of the various presentations that they received. Notably, the only students who reported learning something about authentic laboratory work were those who viewed the video, with or without the presence of the researcher. That being said, the percentages of students who reported learning something about authentic work was still quite low. Perhaps we can do a better job in the future supplementing the video with hands-on laboratory work and other related activities before and after viewing the video. Previous research in the use of educational videos in chemistry teaching contexts demonstrates the value of planned video pauses with explicitly designed discussion questions. This is definitely a strategy that could be implemented with this video in the future. Another interesting finding was that the only students who reported learning nothing were those in classes where the chemist was not present during the experience. This finding indicates that a knowledgeable chemist present during the video playback was a key variable related to learning outcomes. We wonder, if a trained high school teacher, e.g., one who has personal experience conducting professional chemistry research, might be able to substitute for the presence of the chemist. Perhaps what is important is the presence of expertise itself and an expertise that could potentially be had by the high school teacher. This is something that needs future research. It is worth mentioning here that the majority of all of the students in the video only groups (i.e., those that lacked the presence of the expert chemist) did report learning something valuable about the work that chemists do, the applications of MOF chemistry, material chemistry in general, or authentic laboratory work. One limitation to our analysis was that we coded each student to only one category of learning (). We do believe that given the data we had, this was the best that we could do. Had we been able to interview each student, perhaps they would have provided us with more nuanced responses that might have fallen in more than one category.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion and Conclusion

As can be seen from the data presented in , students in general reported learning something as a result of the various presentations that they received. Notably, the only students who reported learning something about authentic laboratory work were those who viewed the video, with or without the presence of the researcher. That being said, the percentages of students who reported learning something about authentic work was still quite low. Perhaps we can do a better job in the future supplementing the video with hands-on laboratory work and other related activities before and after viewing the video. Previous research in the use of educational videos in chemistry teaching contexts demonstrates the value of planned video pauses with explicitly designed discussion questions. This is definitely a strategy that could be implemented with this video in the future. Another interesting finding was that the only students who reported learning nothing were those in classes where the chemist was not present during the experience. This finding indicates that a knowledgeable chemist present during the video playback was a key variable related to learning outcomes. We wonder, if a trained high school teacher, e.g., one who has personal experience conducting professional chemistry research, might be able to substitute for the presence of the chemist. Perhaps what is important is the presence of expertise itself and an expertise that could potentially be had by the high school teacher. This is something that needs future research. It is worth mentioning here that the majority of all of the students in the video only groups (i.e., those that lacked the presence of the expert chemist) did report learning something valuable about the work that chemists do, the applications of MOF chemistry, material chemistry in general, or authentic laboratory work. One limitation to our analysis was that we coded each student to only one category of learning (). We do believe that given the data we had, this was the best that we could do. Had we been able to interview each student, perhaps they would have provided us with more nuanced responses that might have fallen in more than one category.

elements.content: We believe that this information demonstrates the value of a chemist-generated research-related video for the purposes of introducing high school chemistry students to authentic chemistry research and related concepts. This is particularly important because visiting individual classrooms in high school settings is quite time-consuming and requires a good deal of planning. A video, however, can be played whenever a high school teacher might find a good fit within the curriculum and can be easily accessed through web-based tools such as YouTube.
elements.clean_text: We believe that this information demonstrates the value of a chemist-generated research-related video for the purposes of introducing high school chemistry students to authentic chemistry research and related concepts. This is particularly important because visiting individual classrooms in high school settings is quite time-consuming and requires a good deal of planning. A video, however, can be played whenever a high school teacher might find a good fit within the curriculum and can be easily accessed through web-based tools such as YouTube.

elements.content: We would be remiss to not mention the clear timeliness of this research for at least two reasons. First, with the current rush to develop and empirically test the merits of both therapeutics and vaccinations for the COVID-19 virus, students’ interest in the development of any drug and subsequent trials, specifically the time that it takes to do this sort of medical research, is piqued. That students asked so many questions about the practical applications of MOF chemistry is an encouraging sign of the effectiveness of our video. Second, with schools and universities across the globe closed and delivering remote instruction, the practical use of online videos as educational tools has been amplified. This video in particular simulates bringing students into a laboratory. Such an experience is likely extremely valuable during times when physical access to laboratories might be prohibited due to a pandemic, e.g., COVID-19.
elements.clean_text: We would be remiss to not mention the clear timeliness of this research for at least two reasons. First, with the current rush to develop and empirically test the merits of both therapeutics and vaccinations for the COVID-19 virus, students' interest in the development of any drug and subsequent trials, specifically the time that it takes to do this sort of medical research, is piqued. That students asked so many questions about the practical applications of MOF chemistry is an encouraging sign of the effectiveness of our video. Second, with schools and universities across the globe closed and delivering remote instruction, the practical use of online videos as educational tools has been amplified. This video in particular simulates bringing students into a laboratory. Such an experience is likely extremely valuable during times when physical access to laboratories might be prohibited due to a pandemic, e.g., COVID-19.

elements.content: In summary, evidence gathered through this work demonstrated that researcher developed documentary style films can be employed to communicate attributes of authentic scientific research that otherwise would be invisible in traditional school science contexts in general and the high school chemistry classroom in particular. It is hoped that this project models an effective strategy that others may employ.
elements.clean_text: In summary, evidence gathered through this work demonstrated that researcher developed documentary style films can be employed to communicate attributes of authentic scientific research that otherwise would be invisible in traditional school science contexts in general and the high school chemistry classroom in particular. It is hoped that this project models an effective strategy that others may employ.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

The URL for the YouTube video referenced throughout this manuscript is https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lqTQfnK9DEU.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Table 1. High School Chemistry Student Self-Reported Impact of Learning about Authentic Chemistry Research in a Variety of Ways

| Participants                | Learning Experience              | Applications of Chemistry (%) | Job of a Chemist (%) | Authentic Laboratory Work (%) | Misc. Learning (%) | No Learning (%) |
|-----------------------------|-----------------------------------|--------------------------------|----------------------|--------------------------------|---------------------|-----------------|
| Standard chemistry class 1 (<italic toggle="yes">N</italic> = 27) | Chemist present: YouTube video | 41                             | 30                   | 7                              | 22                  | 0               |
| Standard chemistry class 2 (<italic toggle="yes">N</italic> = 21) | Chemist present: Powerpoint, no video | 57                             | 10                   | 0                              | 33                  | 0               |
| Standard chemistry class 3 (<italic toggle="yes">N</italic> = 25) | No chemist present: YouTube video | 16                             | 8                    | 8                              | 32                  | 36              |
| Pre-AP chemistry class 1 (<italic toggle="yes">N</italic> = 26) | Chemist present: Powerpoint, no video | 58                             | 15                   | 0                              | 27                  | 0               |
| Pre-AP chemistry class 2 (<italic toggle="yes">N</italic> = 23) | No chemist present: YouTube video | 52.2                           | 4.4                  | 13                             | 17.4                | 13              |
